comment_text.mn36:3.1: This discourse appears to be set after the previous. In both suttas, while Saccaka is impressed by the Buddha, he does not go for refuge or indicate that he has been persuaded by his teachings.
comment_text.mn36:3.4: Bhassappavādaka (“contoversialist”) is unique. | For “pretends to be astute” (paṇḍitavāda) see Monier-Williams under paṇḍitavādin.
comment_text.mn36:4.1: “Development of physical endurance” is kāyabhāvanā, which is not a normal Buddhist term. It is introduced by Saccaka here and collected in DN 33:1.10.117. The literal meaning is “development of the body”, but I translate in accord with the sense.
comment_text.mn36:4.12: Saccaka’s question shows he was aware of the danger of pursuing of extreme practices and the need for balance. It remains the case today that imbalanced and excessive practices lead to physical and mental breakdowns.
comment_text.mn36:5.3: Described as prominent sages of the Ājīvakas at MN 76:53.6 and AN 6.57:7.1. Gosāla was one of the oft-mentioned six ascetic teachers (see below MN 36:48.7), while the other two are unknown outside of these passing mentions. But the phrasing of this passage suggests that they too, like Gosāla, were contemporaries of the Buddha.
comment_text.mn36:5.8: The earliest Jain text speaks of Mahāvīra eating “only every sixth meal, or eighth, or tenth, or twelfth” (Ācāraṅgasūtra 1.8.4.7).
comment_text.mn36:6.7: While pre-Buddhist texts describe a contemplative and reflective culture, they do not contain clear instructions for meditation. It seems that the practice of explicitly teaching meditation methods was an innovation of the Buddha.
comment_text.mn36:10.3: This is a standard response to someone making unwarranted assumptions about personal spiritual development (AN 3.60:18.1, AN 4.35:5.1, MN 127:17.8).
comment_text.mn36:10.5: The Buddha is not speaking about enlightenment, but about his determination to persevere.
comment_text.mn36:11.1: For the idiom na hi nūna, compare AN 8.86:5.3 and AN 4.67:2.1.
comment_text.mn36:17.1: Also at MN 85:15.1 and MN 100:14.1. These similes, which illustrate the importance of detachment from sensual pleasures and the uselessness of fervent austerities, would fit better below, after the austerities and before jhāna (MN 36:30.1). A parallel to this passage preserved in a fragmentary Sanskrit manuscript of the Dīrgha Āgama does indeed place these similes there, while other parallels vary the content or position of the similes to a degree.
comment_text.mn36:17.6: Abhimanthento must be “drilling” rather than “rubbing”, which does not produce fire. See too the simile of the man “drilling” into the head below (MN 36:22.5).
comment_text.mn36:20.2: This, the most gentle of the austere practices, was occasionally recommended by the Buddha as a last resort (MN 20:7.2).
comment_text.mn36:21.2: This practice seems like an extreme form of “breath control” (prāṇayāma) which was a prominent feature of later Yoga. While the breath played an extremely important role in pre-Buddhist texts, no corresponding practice is detailed. However, precursors may be seen in passages such as Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 3.7.16, where in response to Uddālaka’s question, Yājnavalkya says, “He who controls the breath within is the self, the inner controller, the immortal” (yaḥ prāṇamantaro yamayati, eṣa ta ātmāntaryāmyamṛtaḥ). Jaiminīya Brāhmaņa 1.42 describes a practice of deliberate asphyxiation to induce a near-death experience. Varuṇa deprived his son Bhṛgu of breath in order to send him on a journey to the “other world”. There Bhṛgu saw men cutting other men to pieces and eating them, and other sights both horrifying and beautiful, all the while wondering if what he saw was real, before his breath was returned to him.
comment_text.mn36:29.3: His skin was “dingy” (maṅgura, Sanskrit maṅgura or madgura) like the blotchy mud-green of common catfish (clarias magur), which has a dingy greenish or muddy color for camouflage on the riverbed. See also SN 19.14.
comment_text.mn36:31.2: The gentle and pleasant practice of jhāna is contrasted with the fiery austerities. The Bodhisatta had previously developed meditation under his former teachers, which included the practice of jhāna. But there the practice was embedded in theory, since he first memorized scripture, which would have taught him that such states were a revelation of the true self as the cosmic divinity of sheer consciousness. Thus what he rejected was “that teaching”, i.e. the system of philosophy and practice as a whole, which leads only to rebirth in a realm that, for all its sublimity, is still conditioned. Now he recalls entering deep meditation with the innocence of youth, following no system or philosophy. This showed him that peace of mind is a natural process of letting go, not dependent on (Upaniṣadic) metaphysics.
comment_text.mn36:33.2: The dependence of the mind on food was proven by Uddālaka when he asked Śvetaketu to go without food for fifteen days, after which he could not recall any of the hymns (Chāndogya Upaniṣad 6.7). | Note how this contrasts with the unhealthy cycle of starving and fattening described above (MN 36:6.5).
comment_text.mn36:45.1: This passage is unique and its purpose here unclear,
comment_text.mn36:45.6: Here samādhinimitta as usual means the subject of meditation, probably the breath. | Niccakappa (“continuously”) occurs only here and at MN 144:11.2 = SN 35.87:11.2 where it also used in the sense of “regular subject of contemplation”.
comment_text.mn36:45.7: Saccaka is not saying that the Buddha is enlightened, merely he is like one who is enlightened (yathā taṁ arahato).
comment_text.mn36:45.8: Saccaka reveals his bad faith; he is more interested in trapping the Buddha than in learning.
comment_text.mn36:46.2: He deflects by pointing to others, as he also did at MN 35:11.4.
comment_text.mn36:48.11: This shows that despite his Jain parentage, and despite his citation of Ājīvakas above, Saccaka was no adherent of these philosophies. It seems that he was a contrarian at heart.

root_text.mn36:6.5: “Yaṁ kho te, aggivessana, purimaṁ pahāya pacchā upacinanti, evaṁ imassa kāyassa ācayāpacayo hoti.
root_text.mn36:6.6: Kinti pana te, aggivessana, cittabhāvanā sutā”ti?

root_text.mn36:7.1: Atha kho bhagavā saccakaṁ nigaṇṭhaputtaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn36:7.2: “yāpi kho te esā, aggivessana, purimā kāyabhāvanā bhāsitā sāpi ariyassa vinaye no dhammikā kāyabhāvanā.
root_text.mn36:7.3: Kāyabhāvanampi kho tvaṁ, aggivessana, na aññāsi, kuto pana tvaṁ cittabhāvanaṁ jānissasi?
root_text.mn36:7.4: Api ca, aggivessana, yathā abhāvitakāyo ca hoti abhāvitacitto ca, bhāvitakāyo ca hoti bhāvitacitto ca.
root_text.mn36:7.5: Taṁ suṇāhi, sādhukaṁ manasi karohi, bhāsissāmī”ti.
root_text.mn36:7.6: “Evaṁ, bho”ti kho saccako nigaṇṭhaputto bhagavato paccassosi.
root_text.mn36:8.1: “Kathañca, aggivessana, abhāvitakāyo ca hoti abhāvitacitto ca?
root_text.mn36:8.2: Idha, aggivessana, assutavato puthujjanassa uppajjati sukhā vedanā.
root_text.mn36:8.3: So sukhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno sukhasārāgī ca hoti sukhasārāgitañca āpajjati.
root_text.mn36:8.5: Sukhāya vedanāya nirodhā uppajjati dukkhā vedanā.
root_text.mn36:8.6: So dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno socati kilamati paridevati urattāḷiṁ kandati sammohaṁ āpajjati.
root_text.mn36:8.7: Tassa kho esā, aggivessana, uppannāpi sukhā vedanā cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati abhāvitattā kāyassa, uppannāpi dukkhā vedanā cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati abhāvitattā cittassa.
root_text.mn36:8.8: Yassa kassaci, aggivessana, evaṁ ubhatopakkhaṁ uppannāpi sukhā vedanā cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati abhāvitattā kāyassa, uppannāpi dukkhā vedanā cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati abhāvitattā cittassa, evaṁ kho, aggivessana, abhāvitakāyo ca hoti abhāvitacitto ca.
root_text.mn36:9.1: Kathañca, aggivessana, bhāvitakāyo ca hoti bhāvitacitto ca?
root_text.mn36:9.2: Idha, aggivessana, sutavato ariyasāvakassa uppajjati sukhā vedanā.
root_text.mn36:9.3: So sukhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno na sukhasārāgī ca hoti, na sukhasārāgitañca āpajjati.
root_text.mn36:9.5: Sukhāya vedanāya nirodhā uppajjati dukkhā vedanā.
root_text.mn36:9.6: So dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno na socati na kilamati na paridevati na urattāḷiṁ kandati na sammohaṁ āpajjati.

root_text.mn36:9.8: Yassa kassaci, aggivessana, evaṁ ubhatopakkhaṁ uppannāpi sukhā vedanā cittaṁ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati bhāvitattā kāyassa, uppannāpi dukkhā vedanā cittaṁ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati bhāvitattā cittassa. Evaṁ kho, aggivessana, bhāvitakāyo ca hoti bhāvitacitto cā”ti.

root_text.mn36:10.5: Yato kho ahaṁ, aggivessana, kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito, taṁ vata me uppannā vā sukhā vedanā cittaṁ pariyādāya ṭhassati, uppannā vā dukkhā vedanā cittaṁ pariyādāya ṭhassatīti netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjatī”ti.

root_text.mn36:12.2: Idha me, aggivessana, pubbeva sambodhā anabhisambuddhassa bodhisattasseva sato etadahosi:
root_text.mn36:12.4: Nayidaṁ sukaraṁ agāraṁ ajjhāvasatā ekantaparipuṇṇaṁ ekantaparisuddhaṁ saṅkhalikhitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ carituṁ.
root_text.mn36:12.5: Yannūnāhaṁ kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajeyyan’ti.
root_text.mn36:13.1: So kho ahaṁ, aggivessana, aparena samayena daharova samāno, susukāḷakeso bhadrena yobbanena samannāgato paṭhamena vayasā, akāmakānaṁ mātāpitūnaṁ assumukhānaṁ rudantānaṁ, kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajiṁ.
root_text.mn36:13.2: So evaṁ pabbajito samāno kiṅkusalagavesī anuttaraṁ santivarapadaṁ pariyesamāno yena āḷāro kālāmo tenupasaṅkamiṁ; upasaṅkamitvā āḷāraṁ kālāmaṁ etadavocaṁ:
root_text.mn36:13.3: ‘icchāmahaṁ, āvuso kālāma, imasmiṁ dhammavinaye brahmacariyaṁ caritun’ti.
root_text.mn36:13.4: Evaṁ vutte, aggivessana, āḷāro kālāmo maṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn36:13.6: tādiso ayaṁ dhammo yattha viññū puriso nacirasseva sakaṁ ācariyakaṁ sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihareyyā’ti.
root_text.mn36:13.7: So kho ahaṁ, aggivessana, nacirasseva khippameva taṁ dhammaṁ pariyāpuṇiṁ.
root_text.mn36:13.8: So kho ahaṁ, aggivessana, tāvatakeneva oṭṭhapahatamattena lapitalāpanamattena ñāṇavādañca vadāmi theravādañca, ‘jānāmi passāmī’ti ca paṭijānāmi, ahañceva aññe ca.

root_text.mn36:15.3: Evaṁ vutte, aggivessana, udako rāmaputto maṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn36:15.5: tādiso ayaṁ dhammo yattha viññū puriso nacirasseva sakaṁ ācariyakaṁ sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihareyyā’ti.
root_text.mn36:15.6: So kho ahaṁ, aggivessana, nacirasseva khippameva taṁ dhammaṁ pariyāpuṇiṁ.
root_text.mn36:15.7: So kho ahaṁ, aggivessana, tāvatakeneva oṭṭhapahatamattena lapitalāpanamattena ñāṇavādañca vadāmi theravādañca, ‘jānāmi passāmī’ti ca paṭijānāmi, ahañceva aññe ca.
root_text.mn36:15.9: ‘na kho rāmo imaṁ dhammaṁ kevalaṁ saddhāmattakena sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharāmīti pavedesi.
root_text.mn36:15.10: Addhā rāmo imaṁ dhammaṁ jānaṁ passaṁ vihāsī’ti.
root_text.mn36:15.11: Atha khvāhaṁ, aggivessana, yena udako rāmaputto tenupasaṅkamiṁ; upasaṅkamitvā udakaṁ rāmaputtaṁ etadavocaṁ:
root_text.mn36:15.12: ‘kittāvatā no āvuso rāmo imaṁ dhammaṁ sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharāmīti pavedesī’ti?
root_text.mn36:15.13: Evaṁ vutte, aggivessana, udako rāmaputto nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṁ pavedesi.
root_text.mn36:15.15: ‘na kho rāmasseva ahosi saddhā, mayhampatthi saddhā;
root_text.mn36:15.16: na kho rāmasseva ahosi vīriyaṁ, mayhampatthi vīriyaṁ;
root_text.mn36:15.17: na kho rāmasseva ahosi sati, mayhampatthi sati;
root_text.mn36:15.18: na kho rāmasseva ahosi samādhi, mayhampatthi samādhi;
root_text.mn36:15.19: na kho rāmasseva ahosi paññā, mayhampatthi paññā;
root_text.mn36:15.20: yannūnāhaṁ yaṁ dhammaṁ rāmo sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharāmīti pavedesi tassa dhammassa sacchikiriyāya padaheyyan’ti.
root_text.mn36:15.21: So kho ahaṁ, aggivessana, nacirasseva khippameva taṁ dhammaṁ sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsiṁ.
root_text.mn36:15.22: Atha khvāhaṁ, aggivessana, yena udako rāmaputto tenupasaṅkamiṁ; upasaṅkamitvā udakaṁ rāmaputtaṁ etadavocaṁ:
root_text.mn36:15.23: ‘ettāvatā no āvuso rāmo imaṁ dhammaṁ sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja pavedesī’ti?
root_text.mn36:15.24: ‘Ettāvatā kho āvuso rāmo imaṁ dhammaṁ sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja pavedesī’ti.
root_text.mn36:15.25: ‘Ahampi kho, āvuso, ettāvatā imaṁ dhammaṁ sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharāmī’ti.
root_text.mn36:15.27: ye mayaṁ āyasmantaṁ tādisaṁ sabrahmacāriṁ passāma.
root_text.mn36:15.28: Iti yaṁ dhammaṁ rāmo sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja pavedesi, taṁ tvaṁ dhammaṁ sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharasi; yaṁ tvaṁ dhammaṁ sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharasi, taṁ dhammaṁ rāmo sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja pavedesi.
root_text.mn36:15.29: Iti yaṁ dhammaṁ rāmo abhiññāsi taṁ tvaṁ dhammaṁ jānāsi; yaṁ tvaṁ dhammaṁ jānāsi taṁ dhammaṁ rāmo abhiññāsi.
root_text.mn36:15.30: Iti yādiso rāmo ahosi tādiso tuvaṁ; yādiso tuvaṁ tādiso rāmo ahosi.
root_text.mn36:15.31: Ehi dāni, āvuso, tuvaṁ imaṁ gaṇaṁ pariharā’ti.
root_text.mn36:15.32: Iti kho, aggivessana, udako rāmaputto sabrahmacārī me samāno ācariyaṭṭhāne ca maṁ ṭhapesi, uḷārāya ca maṁ pūjāya pūjesi.
root_text.mn36:15.34: ‘nāyaṁ dhammo nibbidāya na virāgāya na nirodhāya na upasamāya na abhiññāya na sambodhāya na nibbānāya saṁvattati, yāvadeva nevasaññānāsaññāyatanūpapattiyā’ti.
root_text.mn36:15.35: So kho ahaṁ, aggivessana, taṁ dhammaṁ analaṅkaritvā tasmā dhammā nibbijja apakkamiṁ.
root_text.mn36:16.1: So kho ahaṁ, aggivessana, kiṅkusalagavesī anuttaraṁ santivarapadaṁ pariyesamāno magadhesu anupubbena cārikaṁ caramāno yena uruvelā senānigamo tadavasariṁ.
root_text.mn36:16.2: Tatthaddasaṁ ramaṇīyaṁ bhūmibhāgaṁ, pāsādikañca vanasaṇḍaṁ, nadiñca sandantiṁ setakaṁ supatitthaṁ ramaṇīyaṁ, samantā ca gocaragāmaṁ.
root_text.mn36:16.4: ‘ramaṇīyo vata bho bhūmibhāgo, pāsādiko ca vanasaṇḍo, nadī ca sandati setakā supatitthā ramaṇīyā, samantā ca gocaragāmo.
root_text.mn36:16.6: So kho ahaṁ, aggivessana, tattheva nisīdiṁ
root_text.mn36:17.1: Apissumaṁ, aggivessana, tisso upamā paṭibhaṁsu anacchariyā pubbe assutapubbā.
root_text.mn36:17.2: Seyyathāpi, aggivessana, allaṁ kaṭṭhaṁ sasnehaṁ udake nikkhittaṁ.
root_text.mn36:17.6: api nu so puriso amuṁ allaṁ kaṭṭhaṁ sasnehaṁ, udake nikkhittaṁ, uttarāraṇiṁ ādāya abhimanthento aggiṁ abhinibbatteyya, tejo pātukareyyā”ti?
root_text.mn36:17.9: “Aduñhi, bho gotama, allaṁ kaṭṭhaṁ sasnehaṁ, tañca pana udake nikkhittaṁ.
root_text.mn36:17.10: Yāvadeva ca pana so puriso kilamathassa vighātassa bhāgī assā”ti.
root_text.mn36:17.11: “Evameva kho, aggivessana, ye hi keci samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā kāyena ceva cittena ca kāmehi avūpakaṭṭhā viharanti, yo ca nesaṁ kāmesu kāmacchando kāmasneho kāmamucchā kāmapipāsā kāmapariḷāho, so ca ajjhattaṁ na suppahīno hoti, na suppaṭippassaddho, opakkamikā cepi te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayanti, abhabbāva te ñāṇāya dassanāya anuttarāya sambodhāya.
root_text.mn36:17.12: No cepi te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayanti, abhabbāva te ñāṇāya dassanāya anuttarāya sambodhāya.
root_text.mn36:17.13: Ayaṁ kho maṁ, aggivessana, paṭhamā upamā paṭibhāsi anacchariyā pubbe assutapubbā.
root_text.mn36:18.1: Aparāpi kho maṁ, aggivessana, dutiyā upamā paṭibhāsi anacchariyā pubbe assutapubbā.
root_text.mn36:18.2: Seyyathāpi, aggivessana, allaṁ kaṭṭhaṁ sasnehaṁ, ārakā udakā thale nikkhittaṁ.
root_text.mn36:18.6: api nu so puriso amuṁ allaṁ kaṭṭhaṁ sasnehaṁ, ārakā udakā thale nikkhittaṁ, uttarāraṇiṁ ādāya abhimanthento aggiṁ abhinibbatteyya tejo pātukareyyā”ti?

root_text.mn36:20.2: ‘yannūnāhaṁ dantebhi dantamādhāya, jivhāya tāluṁ āhacca, cetasā cittaṁ abhiniggaṇheyyaṁ abhinippīḷeyyaṁ abhisantāpeyyan’ti.
root_text.mn36:20.3: So kho ahaṁ, aggivessana, dantebhi dantamādhāya, jivhāya tāluṁ āhacca, cetasā cittaṁ abhiniggaṇhāmi abhinippīḷemi abhisantāpemi.
root_text.mn36:20.4: Tassa mayhaṁ, aggivessana, dantebhi dantamādhāya jivhāya tāluṁ āhacca cetasā cittaṁ abhiniggaṇhato abhinippīḷayato abhisantāpayato kacchehi sedā muccanti.
root_text.mn36:20.5: Seyyathāpi, aggivessana, balavā puriso dubbalataraṁ purisaṁ sīse vā gahetvā khandhe vā gahetvā abhiniggaṇheyya abhinippīḷeyya abhisantāpeyya;
root_text.mn36:20.6: evameva kho me, aggivessana, dantebhi dantamādhāya, jivhāya tāluṁ āhacca, cetasā cittaṁ abhiniggaṇhato abhinippīḷayato abhisantāpayato kacchehi sedā muccanti.
root_text.mn36:20.7: Āraddhaṁ kho pana me, aggivessana, vīriyaṁ hoti asallīnaṁ, upaṭṭhitā sati asammuṭṭhā, sāraddho ca pana me kāyo hoti appaṭippassaddho teneva dukkhappadhānena padhānābhitunnassa sato.
root_text.mn36:20.8: Evarūpāpi kho me, aggivessana, uppannā dukkhā vedanā cittaṁ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati.
root_text.mn36:21.3: So kho ahaṁ, aggivessana, mukhato ca nāsato ca assāsapassāse uparundhiṁ.
root_text.mn36:21.4: Tassa mayhaṁ, aggivessana, mukhato ca nāsato ca assāsapassāsesu uparuddhesu kaṇṇasotehi vātānaṁ nikkhamantānaṁ adhimatto saddo hoti.
root_text.mn36:21.5: Seyyathāpi nāma kammāragaggariyā dhamamānāya adhimatto saddo hoti;
root_text.mn36:21.6: evameva kho me, aggivessana, mukhato ca nāsato ca assāsapassāsesu uparuddhesu kaṇṇasotehi vātānaṁ nikkhamantānaṁ adhimatto saddo hoti.
root_text.mn36:21.7: Āraddhaṁ kho pana me, aggivessana, vīriyaṁ hoti asallīnaṁ upaṭṭhitā sati asammuṭṭhā. Sāraddho ca pana me kāyo hoti appaṭippassaddho teneva dukkhappadhānena padhānābhitunnassa sato.
root_text.mn36:21.8: Evarūpāpi kho me, aggivessana, uppannā dukkhā vedanā cittaṁ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati.
root_text.mn36:22.3: So kho ahaṁ, aggivessana, mukhato ca nāsato ca kaṇṇato ca assāsapassāse uparundhiṁ.
root_text.mn36:22.4: Tassa mayhaṁ, aggivessana, mukhato ca nāsato ca kaṇṇato ca assāsapassāsesu uparuddhesu adhimattā vātā muddhani ūhananti.
root_text.mn36:22.5: Seyyathāpi, aggivessana, balavā puriso tiṇhena sikharena muddhani abhimattheyya;
root_text.mn36:22.6: evameva kho me, aggivessana, mukhato ca nāsato ca kaṇṇato ca assāsapassāsesu uparuddhesu adhimattā vātā muddhani ūhananti.

root_text.mn36:22.8: Evarūpāpi kho me, aggivessana, uppannā dukkhā vedanā cittaṁ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati.
root_text.mn36:23.3: So kho ahaṁ, aggivessana, mukhato ca nāsato ca kaṇṇato ca assāsapassāse uparundhiṁ.
root_text.mn36:23.4: Tassa mayhaṁ, aggivessana, mukhato ca nāsato ca kaṇṇato ca assāsapassāsesu uparuddhesu adhimattā sīse sīsavedanā honti.
root_text.mn36:23.5: Seyyathāpi, aggivessana, balavā puriso daḷhena varattakkhaṇḍena sīse sīsaveṭhaṁ dadeyya;
root_text.mn36:23.6: evameva kho me, aggivessana, mukhato ca nāsato ca kaṇṇato ca assāsapassāsesu uparuddhesu adhimattā sīse sīsavedanā honti.

root_text.mn36:25.6: evameva kho me, aggivessana, mukhato ca nāsato ca kaṇṇato ca assāsapassāsesu uparuddhesu adhimatto kāyasmiṁ ḍāho hoti.
root_text.mn36:25.7: Āraddhaṁ kho pana me, aggivessana, vīriyaṁ hoti asallīnaṁ upaṭṭhitā sati asammuṭṭhā. Sāraddho ca pana me kāyo hoti appaṭippassaddho teneva dukkhappadhānena padhānābhitunnassa sato.
root_text.mn36:25.8: Evarūpāpi kho me, aggivessana, uppannā dukkhā vedanā cittaṁ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati.
root_text.mn36:26.1: Apissu maṁ, aggivessana, devatā disvā evamāhaṁsu:
root_text.mn36:26.4: ‘na kālaṅkato samaṇo gotamo, api ca kālaṁ karotī’ti.
root_text.mn36:26.6: ‘na kālaṅkato samaṇo gotamo, napi kālaṁ karoti, arahaṁ samaṇo gotamo, vihāro tveva so arahato evarūpo hotī’ti.
root_text.mn36:27.3: Atha kho maṁ, aggivessana, devatā upasaṅkamitvā etadavocuṁ:
root_text.mn36:27.4: ‘mā kho tvaṁ, mārisa, sabbaso āhārupacchedāya paṭipajji.
root_text.mn36:27.5: Sace kho tvaṁ, mārisa, sabbaso āhārupacchedāya paṭipajjissasi, tassa te mayaṁ dibbaṁ ojaṁ lomakūpehi ajjhohāressāma, tāya tvaṁ yāpessasī’ti.
root_text.mn36:27.7: ‘ahañceva kho pana sabbaso ajajjitaṁ paṭijāneyyaṁ, imā ca me devatā dibbaṁ ojaṁ lomakūpehi ajjhohāreyyuṁ, tāya cāhaṁ yāpeyyaṁ, taṁ mamassa musā’ti.
root_text.mn36:27.8: So kho ahaṁ, aggivessana, tā devatā paccācikkhāmi, ‘halan’ti vadāmi.
root_text.mn36:28.2: ‘yannūnāhaṁ thokaṁ thokaṁ āhāraṁ āhāreyyaṁ, pasataṁ pasataṁ, yadi vā muggayūsaṁ, yadi vā kulatthayūsaṁ, yadi vā kaḷāyayūsaṁ, yadi vā hareṇukayūsan’ti.
root_text.mn36:28.3: So kho ahaṁ, aggivessana, thokaṁ thokaṁ āhāraṁ āhāresiṁ, pasataṁ pasataṁ, yadi vā muggayūsaṁ, yadi vā kulatthayūsaṁ, yadi vā kaḷāyayūsaṁ, yadi vā hareṇukayūsaṁ.
root_text.mn36:28.4: Tassa mayhaṁ, aggivessana, thokaṁ thokaṁ āhāraṁ āhārayato, pasataṁ pasataṁ, yadi vā muggayūsaṁ, yadi vā kulatthayūsaṁ, yadi vā kaḷāyayūsaṁ, yadi vā hareṇukayūsaṁ, adhimattakasimānaṁ patto kāyo hoti.
root_text.mn36:28.5: Seyyathāpi nāma āsītikapabbāni vā kāḷapabbāni vā; evamevassu me aṅgapaccaṅgāni bhavanti tāyevappāhāratāya.
root_text.mn36:28.6: Seyyathāpi nāma oṭṭhapadaṁ; evamevassu me ānisadaṁ hoti tāyevappāhāratāya.
root_text.mn36:28.7: Seyyathāpi nāma vaṭṭanāvaḷī; evamevassu me piṭṭhikaṇṭako uṇṇatāvanato hoti tāyevappāhāratāya.
root_text.mn36:28.8: Seyyathāpi nāma jarasālāya gopānasiyo oluggaviluggā bhavanti; evamevassu me phāsuḷiyo oluggaviluggā bhavanti tāyevappāhāratāya.
root_text.mn36:28.9: Seyyathāpi nāma gambhīre udapāne udakatārakā gambhīragatā okkhāyikā dissanti; evamevassu me akkhikūpesu akkhitārakā gambhīragatā okkhāyikā dissanti tāyevappāhāratāya.
root_text.mn36:28.10: Seyyathāpi nāma tittakālābu āmakacchinno vātātapena samphuṭito hoti sammilāto; evamevassu me sīsacchavi samphuṭitā hoti sammilātā tāyevappāhāratāya.
root_text.mn36:28.11: So kho ahaṁ, aggivessana, udaracchaviṁ parimasissāmīti piṭṭhikaṇṭakaṁyeva pariggaṇhāmi, piṭṭhikaṇṭakaṁ parimasissāmīti udaracchaviṁyeva pariggaṇhāmi, yāvassu me, aggivessana, udaracchavi piṭṭhikaṇṭakaṁ allīnā hoti tāyevappāhāratāya.
root_text.mn36:28.12: So kho ahaṁ, aggivessana, vaccaṁ vā muttaṁ vā karissāmīti tattheva avakujjo papatāmi tāyevappāhāratāya.
root_text.mn36:28.13: So kho ahaṁ, aggivessana, imameva kāyaṁ assāsento pāṇinā gattāni anumajjāmi. Tassa mayhaṁ, aggivessana, pāṇinā gattāni anumajjato pūtimūlāni lomāni kāyasmā papatanti tāyevappāhāratāya.
root_text.mn36:29.1: Apissu maṁ, aggivessana, manussā disvā evamāhaṁsu: ‘kāḷo samaṇo gotamo’ti.
root_text.mn36:29.2: Ekacce manussā evamāhaṁsu: ‘na kāḷo samaṇo gotamo, sāmo samaṇo gotamo’ti.
root_text.mn36:29.3: Ekacce manussā evamāhaṁsu: ‘na kāḷo samaṇo gotamo, napi sāmo, maṅguracchavi samaṇo gotamo’ti.
root_text.mn36:29.4: Yāvassu me, aggivessana, tāva parisuddho chavivaṇṇo pariyodāto upahato hoti tāyevappāhāratāya.
root_text.mn36:30.2: ‘ye kho keci atītamaddhānaṁ samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayiṁsu, etāvaparamaṁ, nayito bhiyyo.
root_text.mn36:30.3: Yepi hi keci anāgatamaddhānaṁ samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayissanti, etāvaparamaṁ, nayito bhiyyo.
root_text.mn36:30.4: Yepi hi keci etarahi samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayanti, etāvaparamaṁ, nayito bhiyyo.
root_text.mn36:30.5: Na kho panāhaṁ imāya kaṭukāya dukkarakārikāya adhigacchāmi uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanavisesaṁ.
root_text.mn36:30.6: Siyā nu kho añño maggo bodhāyā’ti?
root_text.mn36:31.2: ‘abhijānāmi kho panāhaṁ pitu sakkassa kammante sītāya jambucchāyāya nisinno vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharitā.
root_text.mn36:31.3: Siyā nu kho eso maggo bodhāyā’ti?
root_text.mn36:31.4: Tassa mayhaṁ, aggivessana, satānusāri viññāṇaṁ ahosi:
root_text.mn36:32.2: ‘kiṁ nu kho ahaṁ tassa sukhassa bhāyāmi, yaṁ taṁ sukhaṁ aññatreva kāmehi aññatra akusalehi dhammehī’ti?
root_text.mn36:32.4: ‘na kho ahaṁ tassa sukhassa bhāyāmi, yaṁ taṁ sukhaṁ aññatreva kāmehi aññatra akusalehi dhammehī’ti.
root_text.mn36:33.2: ‘na kho taṁ sukaraṁ sukhaṁ adhigantuṁ evaṁ adhimattakasimānaṁ pattakāyena, yannūnāhaṁ oḷārikaṁ āhāraṁ āhāreyyaṁ odanakummāsan’ti.
root_text.mn36:33.3: So kho ahaṁ, aggivessana, oḷārikaṁ āhāraṁ āhāresiṁ odanakummāsaṁ.
root_text.mn36:33.4: Tena kho pana maṁ, aggivessana, samayena pañca bhikkhū paccupaṭṭhitā honti:
root_text.mn36:33.5: ‘yaṁ kho samaṇo gotamo dhammaṁ adhigamissati, taṁ no ārocessatī’ti.
root_text.mn36:33.6: Yato kho ahaṁ, aggivessana, oḷārikaṁ āhāraṁ āhāresiṁ odanakummāsaṁ, atha me te pañca bhikkhū nibbijja pakkamiṁsu:
root_text.mn36:34.1: So kho ahaṁ, aggivessana, oḷārikaṁ āhāraṁ āhāretvā, balaṁ gahetvā, vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja vihāsiṁ.
root_text.mn36:34.2: Evarūpāpi kho me, aggivessana, uppannā sukhā vedanā cittaṁ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati.
root_text.mn36:35-37.1: Vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā ajjhattaṁ sampasādanaṁ cetaso ekodibhāvaṁ avitakkaṁ avicāraṁ samādhijaṁ pītisukhaṁ dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja vihāsiṁ.
root_text.mn36:35-37.2: Evarūpāpi kho me, aggivessana, uppannā sukhā vedanā cittaṁ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati.
root_text.mn36:35-37.3: Pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca vihāsiṁ, sato ca sampajāno. Sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṁvedesiṁ yaṁ taṁ ariyā ācikkhanti: ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja vihāsiṁ.
root_text.mn36:35-37.4: Evarūpāpi kho me, aggivessana, uppannā sukhā vedanā cittaṁ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati.
root_text.mn36:35-37.5: Sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā, pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā, adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja vihāsiṁ.
root_text.mn36:35-37.6: Evarūpāpi kho me, aggivessana, uppannā sukhā vedanā cittaṁ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati.
root_text.mn36:38.1: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmesiṁ.
root_text.mn36:38.2: So anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarāmi, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ …pe… iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarāmi.
root_text.mn36:39.1: Ayaṁ kho me, aggivessana, rattiyā paṭhame yāme paṭhamā vijjā adhigatā;
root_text.mn36:39.2: avijjā vihatā, vijjā uppannā; tamo vihato, āloko uppanno; yathā taṁ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato.
root_text.mn36:39.3: Evarūpāpi kho me, aggivessana, uppannā sukhā vedanā cittaṁ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati.
root_text.mn36:40.1: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte sattānaṁ cutūpapātañāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmesiṁ.
root_text.mn36:40.2: So dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passāmi cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāmi …pe…
root_text.mn36:41.1: ayaṁ kho me, aggivessana, rattiyā majjhime yāme dutiyā vijjā adhigatā;
root_text.mn36:41.2: avijjā vihatā, vijjā uppannā; tamo vihato, āloko uppanno; yathā taṁ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato.
root_text.mn36:41.3: Evarūpāpi kho me, aggivessana, uppannā sukhā vedanā cittaṁ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati.
root_text.mn36:42.1: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte āsavānaṁ khayañāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmesiṁ.
root_text.mn36:42.2: So ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ, ‘ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ.
root_text.mn36:42.3: ‘Ime āsavā’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ, ‘ayaṁ āsavasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ, ‘ayaṁ āsavanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ, ‘ayaṁ āsavanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ.
root_text.mn36:43.1: Tassa me evaṁ jānato evaṁ passato kāmāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccittha, bhavāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccittha, avijjāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccittha.
root_text.mn36:43.3: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā’ti abbhaññāsiṁ.
root_text.mn36:44.1: Ayaṁ kho me, aggivessana, rattiyā pacchime yāme tatiyā vijjā adhigatā;
root_text.mn36:44.2: avijjā vihatā, vijjā uppannā; tamo vihato, āloko uppanno; yathā taṁ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato.
root_text.mn36:44.3: Evarūpāpi kho me, aggivessana, uppannā sukhā vedanā cittaṁ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati.
root_text.mn36:45.1: Abhijānāmi kho panāhaṁ, aggivessana, anekasatāya parisāya dhammaṁ desetā.
root_text.mn36:45.4: Na kho panetaṁ, aggivessana, evaṁ daṭṭhabbaṁ;
root_text.mn36:45.5: yāvadeva viññāpanatthāya tathāgato paresaṁ dhammaṁ deseti.
root_text.mn36:45.6: So kho ahaṁ, aggivessana, tassāyeva kathāya pariyosāne, tasmiṁyeva purimasmiṁ samādhinimitte ajjhattameva cittaṁ saṇṭhapemi sannisādemi ekodiṁ karomi samādahāmi, yena sudaṁ niccakappaṁ viharāmī”ti.
root_text.mn36:45.7: “Okappaniyametaṁ bhoto gotamassa yathā taṁ arahato sammāsambuddhassa.
root_text.mn36:45.8: Abhijānāti kho pana bhavaṁ gotamo divā supitā”ti?
root_text.mn36:46.1: “Abhijānāmahaṁ, aggivessana, gimhānaṁ pacchime māse pacchābhattaṁ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto catugguṇaṁ saṅghāṭiṁ paññapetvā dakkhiṇena passena sato sampajāno niddaṁ okkamitā”ti.
root_text.mn36:46.2: “Etaṁ kho, bho gotama, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā sammohavihārasmiṁ vadantī”ti?
root_text.mn36:46.3: “Na kho, aggivessana, ettāvatā sammūḷho vā hoti asammūḷho vā.
root_text.mn36:46.4: Api ca, aggivessana, yathā sammūḷho ca hoti asammūḷho ca,
root_text.mn36:46.5: taṁ suṇāhi, sādhukaṁ manasi karohi, bhāsissāmī”ti.
root_text.mn36:46.6: “Evaṁ, bho”ti kho saccako nigaṇṭhaputto bhagavato paccassosi.
root_text.mn36:47.1: “Yassa kassaci, aggivessana, ye āsavā saṅkilesikā ponobbhavikā sadarā dukkhavipākā āyatiṁ jātijarāmaraṇiyā appahīnā, tamahaṁ ‘sammūḷho’ti vadāmi.
root_text.mn36:47.3: Yassa kassaci, aggivessana, ye āsavā saṅkilesikā ponobbhavikā sadarā dukkhavipākā āyatiṁ jātijarāmaraṇiyā pahīnā, tamahaṁ ‘asammūḷho’ti vadāmi.
root_text.mn36:47.5: Tathāgatassa kho, aggivessana, ye āsavā saṅkilesikā ponobbhavikā sadarā dukkhavipākā āyatiṁ jātijarāmaraṇiyā pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṁ anuppādadhammā.
root_text.mn36:47.6: Seyyathāpi, aggivessana, tālo matthakacchinno abhabbo puna virūḷhiyā;
root_text.mn36:47.7: evameva kho, aggivessana, tathāgatassa ye āsavā saṅkilesikā ponobbhavikā sadarā dukkhavipākā āyatiṁ jātijarāmaraṇiyā pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṁ anuppādadhammā”ti.
root_text.mn36:48.1: Evaṁ vutte, saccako nigaṇṭhaputto bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn36:48.3: Yāvañcidaṁ bhoto gotamassa evaṁ āsajja āsajja vuccamānassa, upanītehi vacanappathehi samudācariyamānassa, chavivaṇṇo ceva pariyodāyati, mukhavaṇṇo ca vippasīdati, yathā taṁ arahato sammāsambuddhassa.
root_text.mn36:48.4: Abhijānāmahaṁ, bho gotama, pūraṇaṁ kassapaṁ vādena vādaṁ samārabhitā.
root_text.mn36:48.5: Sopi mayā vādena vādaṁ samāraddho aññenaññaṁ paṭicari, bahiddhā kathaṁ apanāmesi, kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātvākāsi.
root_text.mn36:48.6: Bhoto pana gotamassa evaṁ āsajja āsajja vuccamānassa, upanītehi vacanappathehi samudācariyamānassa, chavivaṇṇo ceva pariyodāyati, mukhavaṇṇo ca vippasīdati, yathā taṁ arahato sammāsambuddhassa.
root_text.mn36:48.12: Sopi mayā vādena vādaṁ samāraddho aññenaññaṁ paṭicari, bahiddhā kathaṁ apanāmesi, kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātvākāsi.
root_text.mn36:48.13: Bhoto pana gotamassa evaṁ āsajja āsajja vuccamānassa, upanītehi vacanappathehi samudācariyamānassa, chavivaṇṇo ceva pariyodāyati, mukhavaṇṇo ca vippasīdati, yathā taṁ arahato sammāsambuddhassa.
root_text.mn36:48.14: Handa ca dāni mayaṁ, bho gotama, gacchāma.
root_text.mn36:48.17: Atha kho saccako nigaṇṭhaputto bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkāmīti.

translation_text.mn36:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
translation_text.mn36:2.1: Now at that time in the morning the Buddha, being properly dressed, took his bowl and robe, wishing to enter Vesālī for alms.
translation_text.mn36:3.1: Then as Saccaka, the son of Jain parents, was going for a walk he approached the hall with the peaked roof in the Great Wood.
translation_text.mn36:3.2: Venerable Ānanda saw him coming off in the distance,
translation_text.mn36:3.4: “Sir, Saccaka, the son of Jain parents, is coming. He’s a controversialist who pretends to be astute and is deemed holy by many people.
translation_text.mn36:3.5: He wants to discredit the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha.
translation_text.mn36:3.6: Please, sir, sit for an hour out of sympathy.”
translation_text.mn36:3.7: The Buddha sat on the seat spread out.
translation_text.mn36:3.8: Then Saccaka went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him. When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha,
translation_text.mn36:4.1: “Worthy Gotama, there are some ascetics and brahmins who live committed to the practice of developing physical endurance, without developing the mind.
translation_text.mn36:4.3: This happened to someone once. Their thighs became paralyzed, their heart burst, hot blood gushed from their mouth, and they went mad and lost their mind.
translation_text.mn36:4.4: Their mind was subject to the body, and the body had power over it.
translation_text.mn36:4.6: Because their mind was not developed.
translation_text.mn36:4.7: There are some ascetics and brahmins who live committed to the practice of developing the mind, without developing physical endurance.
translation_text.mn36:4.9: This happened to someone once. Their thighs became paralyzed, their heart burst, hot blood gushed from their mouth, and they went mad and lost their mind.
translation_text.mn36:4.10: Their body was subject to the mind, and the mind had power over it.
translation_text.mn36:4.12: Because their physical endurance was not developed.
translation_text.mn36:4.14: The worthy Gotama’s disciples must live committed to the practice of developing the mind, without developing physical endurance.”
translation_text.mn36:5.1: “But Aggivessana, what have you heard about the development of physical endurance?”
translation_text.mn36:5.3: Nanda Vaccha, Kisa Saṅkicca, and the bamboo-staffed ascetic Gosāla.
translation_text.mn36:5.4: They go naked, ignoring conventions. They lick their hands, and don’t come or wait when called. They don’t consent to food brought to them, or food prepared on their behalf, or an invitation for a meal.
translation_text.mn36:5.5: They don’t receive anything from a pot or bowl; or from someone who keeps sheep, or who has a weapon or a shovel in their home; or where a couple is eating; or where there is a woman who is pregnant, breastfeeding, or who lives with a man; or where there’s a hound waiting or flies buzzing. They accept no fish or meat or beer or wine, and drink no fermented gruel.
translation_text.mn36:5.6: They go to just one house for alms, taking just one mouthful, or two houses and two mouthfuls, up to seven houses and seven mouthfuls.
translation_text.mn36:5.7: They feed on one saucer a day, two saucers a day, up to seven saucers a day.
translation_text.mn36:5.8: They eat once a day, once every second day, up to once a week, and so on, even up to once a fortnight. They live committed to the practice of eating food at set intervals.”
translation_text.mn36:6.1: “But Aggivessana, do they get by on so little?”
translation_text.mn36:6.3: Sometimes they eat luxury fresh and cooked foods and drink a variety of luxury beverages.
translation_text.mn36:6.4: They gather their body’s strength, build it up, and get fat.”
translation_text.mn36:6.5: “What they earlier gave up, they later got back. That is how there is the increase and decrease of this body.
translation_text.mn36:6.6: But Aggivessana, what have you heard about development of the mind?”
translation_text.mn36:6.7: When Saccaka was questioned by the Buddha about development of the mind, he was stumped.
translation_text.mn36:7.1: So the Buddha said to Saccaka,
translation_text.mn36:7.2: “The development of physical endurance that you have described is not the legitimate development of physical endurance in the noble one’s training.
translation_text.mn36:7.3: And since you don’t even understand the development of physical endurance, how can you possibly understand the development of the mind?
translation_text.mn36:7.4: Still, as to how someone is undeveloped in physical endurance and mind, and how someone is developed in physical endurance and mind,
translation_text.mn36:7.5: listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
translation_text.mn36:8.1: “And how is someone undeveloped in physical endurance and mind?
translation_text.mn36:8.2: Take an unlearned ordinary person who has a pleasant feeling.
translation_text.mn36:8.3: When they experience a pleasant feeling they become full of lust for it.
translation_text.mn36:8.5: And when it ceases, a painful feeling arises.
translation_text.mn36:8.6: When they suffer painful feeling, they sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.
translation_text.mn36:8.7: Because their physical endurance is undeveloped, pleasant feelings occupy the mind. And because their mind is undeveloped, painful feelings occupy the mind.
translation_text.mn36:8.8: Anyone whose mind is occupied by both pleasant and painful feelings like this is undeveloped both in physical endurance and in mind.
translation_text.mn36:9.1: And how is someone developed in physical endurance and mind?
translation_text.mn36:9.2: Take a learned noble disciple who has a pleasant feeling.
translation_text.mn36:9.3: When they experience a pleasant feeling they don’t become full of lust for it.
translation_text.mn36:9.5: And when it ceases, painful feeling arises.
translation_text.mn36:9.6: When they suffer painful feelings they don’t sorrow or wail or lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.
translation_text.mn36:9.7: Because their physical endurance is developed, pleasant feelings don’t occupy the mind. And because their mind is developed, painful feelings don’t occupy the mind.
translation_text.mn36:9.8: Anyone whose mind is not occupied by both pleasant and painful feelings like this is developed both in physical endurance and in mind.”
translation_text.mn36:10.1: “I am quite confident that the worthy Gotama
translation_text.mn36:10.2: is developed in physical endurance and in mind.”
translation_text.mn36:10.3: “Your words are clearly invasive and intrusive, Aggivessana.
translation_text.mn36:10.5: Ever since I shaved off my hair and beard, dressed in ocher robes, and went forth from the lay life to homelessness, it has not been possible for any pleasant or painful feeling to occupy my mind.”
translation_text.mn36:11.1: “Worthy Gotama mustn’t have experienced the kind of pleasant or painful feelings that would occupy the mind.”
translation_text.mn36:12.2: Before my awakening—when I was still unawakened but intent on awakening—I thought:
translation_text.mn36:12.3: ‘Life at home is cramped and dirty, life gone forth is wide open.
translation_text.mn36:12.4: It’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.
translation_text.mn36:12.5: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’
translation_text.mn36:13.1: Some time later, while still with pristine black hair, blessed with youth, in the prime of life—though my mother and father wished otherwise, weeping with tearful faces—I shaved off my hair and beard, dressed in ocher robes, and went forth from the lay life to homelessness.
translation_text.mn36:13.2: Once I had gone forth I set out to discover what is skillful, seeking the supreme state of sublime peace. I approached Āḷāra Kālāma and said to him,
translation_text.mn36:13.3: ‘Reverend Kālāma, I wish to lead the spiritual life in this teaching and training.’
translation_text.mn36:13.6: This teaching is such that a sensible person can soon realize their own tradition with their own insight and live having achieved it.’
translation_text.mn36:13.8: As far as lip-recital and verbal repetition went, I spoke the doctrine of knowledge, the elder doctrine. I claimed to know and see, and so did others.
translation_text.mn36:13.10: ‘It is not solely by mere faith that Āḷāra Kālāma declares: “I realize this teaching with my own insight, and live having achieved it.”
translation_text.mn36:13.11: Surely he meditates knowing and seeing this teaching.’
translation_text.mn36:13.12: So I approached Āḷāra Kālāma and said to him,
translation_text.mn36:13.13: ‘Reverend Kālāma, to what extent do you say you’ve realized this teaching with your own insight?’
translation_text.mn36:13.14: When I said this, he declared the dimension of nothingness.
translation_text.mn36:13.16: ‘It’s not just Āḷāra Kālāma who has faith,
translation_text.mn36:13.20: and wisdom; I too have these things.
translation_text.mn36:13.21: Why don’t I make an effort to realize the same teaching that Āḷāra Kālāma says he has realized with his own insight?’
translation_text.mn36:13.22: I quickly realized that teaching with my own insight, and lived having achieved it.
translation_text.mn36:14.1: So I approached Āḷāra Kālāma and said to him,
translation_text.mn36:14.2: ‘Reverend Kālāma, is it up to this point that you realized this teaching with your own insight, and declare having achieved it?’
translation_text.mn36:14.4: ‘I too have realized this teaching with my own insight up to this point, and live having achieved it.’
translation_text.mn36:14.5: ‘We are fortunate, reverend, so very fortunate
translation_text.mn36:14.6: to see a venerable such as yourself as one of our spiritual companions!
translation_text.mn36:14.7: So the teaching that I’ve realized with my own insight, and declare having achieved it, you’ve realized with your own insight, and dwell having achieved it.
translation_text.mn36:14.8: The teaching that you’ve realized with your own insight, and dwell having achieved it, I’ve realized with my own insight, and declare having achieved it.
translation_text.mn36:14.9: So the teaching that I know, you know, and the teaching you know, I know.
translation_text.mn36:14.10: I am like you and you are like me.
translation_text.mn36:14.11: Come now, reverend! We should both lead this community together.’
translation_text.mn36:14.12: And that is how my tutor Āḷāra Kālāma placed me, his pupil, on the same position as him, and honored me with high praise.
translation_text.mn36:14.14: ‘This teaching doesn’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. It only leads as far as rebirth in the dimension of nothingness.’
translation_text.mn36:14.15: Realizing that this teaching was inadequate, I left disappointed.

translation_text.mn36:15.2: ‘Reverend, I wish to lead the spiritual life in this teaching and training.’
translation_text.mn36:15.5: This teaching is such that a sensible person can soon realize their own tradition with their own insight and live having achieved it.’
translation_text.mn36:15.7: As far as lip-recital and verbal repetition went, I spoke the doctrine of knowledge, the elder doctrine. I claimed to know and see, and so did others.

translation_text.mn36:16.1: I set out to discover what is skillful, seeking the supreme state of sublime peace. Traveling stage by stage in the Magadhan lands, I arrived at the town of Senā in Uruvelā.
translation_text.mn36:16.2: There I saw a delightful park, a lovely grove with a flowing river that was clean and charming, with smooth banks. And nearby was a village to resort to for alms.
translation_text.mn36:16.4: ‘This park is truly delightful, a lovely grove with a flowing river that’s clean and charming, with smooth banks. And nearby there’s a village to resort to for alms.
translation_text.mn36:16.5: This is good enough for striving for a gentleman wanting to strive.’
translation_text.mn36:16.6: So I sat down right there, thinking:
translation_text.mn36:17.1: And then these three similes, which were neither supernaturally inspired, nor learned before in the past, occurred to me.
translation_text.mn36:17.2: Suppose there was a green, sappy log, and it was lying in water.
translation_text.mn36:17.3: Then a person comes along with a drill-stick, thinking
translation_text.mn36:17.4: to light a fire and produce heat.
translation_text.mn36:17.6: By drilling the stick against that green, sappy log lying in the water, could they light a fire and produce heat?”
translation_text.mn36:17.9: Because it’s a green, sappy log, and it’s lying in the water.
translation_text.mn36:17.10: That person will eventually get weary and frustrated.”
translation_text.mn36:17.11: “In the same way, there are ascetics and brahmins who don’t live withdrawn in body and mind from sensual pleasures. They haven’t internally given up or stilled desire, affection, infatuation, thirst, and passion for sensual pleasures. Regardless of whether or not they feel painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion, they are incapable of knowledge and vision, of supreme awakening.
translation_text.mn36:17.13: This was the first example that occurred to me.
translation_text.mn36:18.1: Then a second example occurred to me.
translation_text.mn36:18.2: Suppose there was a green, sappy log, and it was lying on dry land far from the water.
translation_text.mn36:18.3: Then a person comes along with a drill-stick, thinking
translation_text.mn36:18.4: to light a fire and produce heat.
translation_text.mn36:18.6: By drilling the stick against that green, sappy log on dry land far from water, could they light a fire and produce heat?”
translation_text.mn36:18.9: Because it’s still a green, sappy log, despite the fact that it’s lying on dry land far from water.
translation_text.mn36:18.10: That person will eventually get weary and frustrated.”
translation_text.mn36:18.11: “In the same way, there are ascetics and brahmins who live withdrawn in body and mind from sensual pleasures. But they haven’t internally given up or stilled desire, affection, infatuation, thirst, and passion for sensual pleasures. Regardless of whether or not they suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion, they are incapable of knowledge and vision, of supreme awakening.
translation_text.mn36:18.12: This was the second example that occurred to me.
translation_text.mn36:19.1: Then a third example occurred to me.
translation_text.mn36:19.2: Suppose there was a dried up, withered log, and it was lying on dry land far from the water.
translation_text.mn36:19.3: Then a person comes along with a drill-stick, thinking
translation_text.mn36:19.4: to light a fire and produce heat.
translation_text.mn36:19.6: By drilling the stick against that dried up, withered log on dry land far from water, could they light a fire and produce heat?”
translation_text.mn36:19.9: Because it’s a dried up, withered log, and it’s lying on dry land far from water.”
translation_text.mn36:19.10: “In the same way, there are ascetics and brahmins who live withdrawn in body and mind from sensual pleasures. And they have internally given up and stilled desire, affection, infatuation, thirst, and passion for sensual pleasures. Regardless of whether or not they suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion, they are capable of knowledge and vision, of supreme awakening.
translation_text.mn36:19.11: This was the third example that occurred to me.
translation_text.mn36:19.12: These are the three similes, which were neither supernaturally inspired, nor learned before in the past, that occurred to me.
translation_text.mn36:20.2: ‘Why don’t I, with teeth clenched and tongue pressed against the roof of my mouth, squeeze, squash, and scorch mind with mind?’
translation_text.mn36:20.4: until sweat ran from my armpits.
translation_text.mn36:20.5: It was like when a strong man grabs a weaker man by the head or throat or shoulder and squeezes, squashes, and crushes them.
translation_text.mn36:20.6: In the same way, with teeth clenched and tongue pressed against the roof of my mouth, I squeezed, squashed, and crushed mind with mind until sweat ran from my armpits.
translation_text.mn36:20.7: My energy was roused up and unflagging, and my mindfulness was established and lucid, but my body was disturbed, not tranquil, because I’d pushed too hard with that painful striving.
translation_text.mn36:20.8: But even such painful feeling did not occupy my mind.
translation_text.mn36:21.2: ‘Why don’t I practice the breathless absorption?’
translation_text.mn36:21.3: So I cut off my breathing through my mouth and nose.
translation_text.mn36:21.4: But then winds came out my ears making a loud noise,
translation_text.mn36:21.5: like the puffing of a blacksmith’s bellows.
translation_text.mn36:21.7: My energy was roused up and unflagging, and my mindfulness was established and lucid, but my body was disturbed, not tranquil, because I’d pushed too hard with that painful striving.
translation_text.mn36:21.8: But even such painful feeling did not occupy my mind.
translation_text.mn36:22.2: ‘Why don’t I keep practicing the breathless absorption?’
translation_text.mn36:22.3: So I cut off my breathing through my mouth and nose and ears.
translation_text.mn36:22.4: But then strong winds ground my head,
translation_text.mn36:22.5: like a strong man was drilling into my head with a sharp point.
translation_text.mn36:22.7: My energy was roused up and unflagging, and my mindfulness was established and lucid, but my body was disturbed, not tranquil, because I’d pushed too hard with that painful striving.
translation_text.mn36:22.8: But even such painful feeling did not occupy my mind.
translation_text.mn36:23.2: ‘Why don’t I keep practicing the breathless absorption?’
translation_text.mn36:23.3: So I cut off my breathing through my mouth and nose and ears.
translation_text.mn36:23.4: But then I got a severe headache,
translation_text.mn36:23.5: like a strong man was tightening a strong leather strap around my head.
translation_text.mn36:23.7: My energy was roused up and unflagging, and my mindfulness was established and lucid, but my body was disturbed, not tranquil, because I’d pushed too hard with that painful striving.
translation_text.mn36:23.8: But even such painful feeling did not occupy my mind.
translation_text.mn36:24.2: ‘Why don’t I keep practicing the breathless absorption?’
translation_text.mn36:24.3: So I cut off my breathing through my mouth and nose and ears.
translation_text.mn36:24.4: But then strong winds carved up my belly,
translation_text.mn36:24.5: like a deft butcher or their apprentice was slicing my belly open with a sharp meat cleaver.
translation_text.mn36:24.7: My energy was roused up and unflagging, and my mindfulness was established and lucid, but my body was disturbed, not tranquil, because I’d pushed too hard with that painful striving.
translation_text.mn36:24.8: But even such painful feeling did not occupy my mind.

translation_text.mn36:25.3: So I cut off my breathing through my mouth and nose and ears.
translation_text.mn36:25.4: But then there was a severe burning in my body,
translation_text.mn36:25.5: like two strong men grabbing a weaker man by the arms to burn and scorch him on a pit of glowing coals.
translation_text.mn36:25.7: My energy was roused up and unflagging, and my mindfulness was established and lucid, but my body was disturbed, not tranquil, because I’d pushed too hard with that painful striving.
translation_text.mn36:25.8: But even such painful feeling did not occupy my mind.
translation_text.mn36:26.1: Then some deities saw me and said,
translation_text.mn36:26.6: ‘He’s not dead or dying. The ascetic Gotama is a perfected one, for that is how the perfected ones live.’
translation_text.mn36:27.2: ‘Why don’t I practice completely cutting off food?’
translation_text.mn36:27.3: But deities came to me and said,
translation_text.mn36:27.4: ‘Good fellow, don’t practice totally cutting off food.
translation_text.mn36:27.5: If you do, we’ll infuse heavenly nectar into your pores and you will live on that.’
translation_text.mn36:27.7: ‘If I claim to be completely fasting while these deities are infusing heavenly nectar in my pores, that would be a lie on my part.’
translation_text.mn36:27.8: So I refused those deities, saying, ‘There’s no need.’
translation_text.mn36:28.2: ‘Why don’t I just take a little bit of food each time, a handful of broth made from mung beans, horse gram, chickpeas, or green gram?’
translation_text.mn36:28.4: until my body became severely emaciated.
translation_text.mn36:28.5: Due to eating so little, my major and minor limbs became like the joints of an eighty-year-old or a dying man,
translation_text.mn36:28.6: my bottom became like a camel’s hoof,
translation_text.mn36:28.7: my vertebrae stuck out like beads on a string,
translation_text.mn36:28.8: and my ribs were as gaunt as the broken-down rafters on an old barn.
translation_text.mn36:28.9: Due to eating so little, the gleam of my eyes sank deep in their sockets, like the gleam of water sunk deep down a well.
translation_text.mn36:28.10: Due to eating so little, my scalp shriveled and withered like a green bitter-gourd in the wind and sun.
translation_text.mn36:28.11: Due to eating so little, the skin of my belly stuck to my backbone, so that when I tried to rub the skin of my belly I grabbed my backbone, and when I tried to rub my backbone I rubbed the skin of my belly.
translation_text.mn36:28.12: Due to eating so little, when I tried to urinate or defecate I fell face down right there.
translation_text.mn36:28.13: Due to eating so little, when I tried to relieve my body by rubbing my limbs with my hands, the hair, rotted at its roots, fell out.
translation_text.mn36:29.1: Then some people saw me and said: ‘The ascetic Gotama is black.’
translation_text.mn36:29.2: Some said: ‘He’s not black, he’s brown.’
translation_text.mn36:29.3: Some said: ‘He’s neither black nor brown. The ascetic Gotama has dingy skin.’
translation_text.mn36:29.4: That’s how far the pure, bright complexion of my skin had been ruined by taking so little food.
translation_text.mn36:30.2: ‘Whatever ascetics and brahmins have experienced painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion—whether in the past, future, or present—this is as far as it goes, no-one has done more than this.
translation_text.mn36:30.5: But I have not achieved any superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones by this severe, grueling work.
translation_text.mn36:30.6: Could there be another path to awakening?’
translation_text.mn36:31.2: ‘I recall sitting in the cool shade of a black plum tree while my father the Sakyan was off working. Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, I entered and remained in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.mn36:31.3: Could that be the path to awakening?’
translation_text.mn36:31.4: Stemming from that memory came the understanding:
translation_text.mn36:32.2: ‘Why am I afraid of that pleasure, for it has nothing to do with sensual pleasures or unskillful qualities?’
translation_text.mn36:32.4: ‘I’m not afraid of that pleasure, for it has nothing to do with sensual pleasures or unskillful qualities.’
translation_text.mn36:33.2: ‘I can’t achieve that pleasure with a body so severely emaciated. Why don’t I eat some solid food, some rice and porridge?’
translation_text.mn36:33.3: So I ate some solid food.
translation_text.mn36:33.4: Now at that time the five mendicants were attending on me, thinking,
translation_text.mn36:33.5: ‘The ascetic Gotama will tell us of any truth that he realizes.’
translation_text.mn36:33.6: But when I ate some solid food, they left disappointed in me, saying,
translation_text.mn36:33.7: ‘The ascetic Gotama has become indulgent; he has strayed from the struggle and returned to indulgence.’
translation_text.mn36:34.1: After eating solid food and gathering my strength, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, I entered and remained in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.mn36:34.2: But even such pleasant feeling did not occupy my mind.
translation_text.mn36:35-37.1: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected were stilled, I entered and remained in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.mn36:35-37.2: But even such pleasant feeling did not occupy my mind.
translation_text.mn36:35-37.3: And with the fading away of rapture, I entered and remained in the third absorption, where I meditated with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’
translation_text.mn36:35-37.4: But even such pleasant feeling did not occupy my mind.
translation_text.mn36:35-37.5: With the giving up of pleasure and pain, and the ending of former happiness and sadness, I entered and remained in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
translation_text.mn36:35-37.6: But even such pleasant feeling did not occupy my mind.
translation_text.mn36:38.1: When my mind had immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—I extended it toward recollection of past lives.
translation_text.mn36:38.2: I recollected my many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
translation_text.mn36:39.1: This was the first knowledge, which I achieved in the first watch of the night.
translation_text.mn36:39.2: Ignorance was banished and knowledge arose; darkness was banished and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.
translation_text.mn36:39.3: But even such pleasant feeling did not occupy my mind.
translation_text.mn36:40.1: When my mind had immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—I extended it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.
translation_text.mn36:40.2: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, I saw sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. I understood how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds.
translation_text.mn36:41.1: This was the second knowledge, which I achieved in the middle watch of the night.
translation_text.mn36:41.2: Ignorance was banished and knowledge arose; darkness was banished and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.
translation_text.mn36:41.3: But even such pleasant feeling did not occupy my mind.
translation_text.mn36:42.1: When my mind had immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—I extended it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
translation_text.mn36:42.2: I truly understood: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’
translation_text.mn36:42.3: I truly understood: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements.’
translation_text.mn36:43.1: Knowing and seeing like this, my mind was freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
translation_text.mn36:43.2: When it was freed, I knew it was freed.
translation_text.mn36:43.3: I understood: ‘Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.’
translation_text.mn36:44.1: This was the third knowledge, which I achieved in the last watch of the night.
translation_text.mn36:44.2: Ignorance was banished and knowledge arose; darkness was banished and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.
translation_text.mn36:44.3: But even such pleasant feeling did not occupy my mind.
translation_text.mn36:45.1: Aggivessana, I recall teaching the Dhamma to an assembly of many hundreds,
translation_text.mn36:45.3: that I was teaching the Dhamma especially for them.
translation_text.mn36:45.4: But it should not be seen like this.
translation_text.mn36:45.5: The Realized One teaches others only so that they can understand.
translation_text.mn36:45.6: When that talk was finished, I stilled, settled, unified, and immersed my mind in samādhi internally, using the same meditation subject as a basis of immersion that I used before, which I regularly use to meditate.”
translation_text.mn36:45.7: “I’d believe that of the worthy Gotama, just like a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha.
translation_text.mn36:45.8: But do you ever recall sleeping during the day?”
translation_text.mn36:46.1: “I do recall that in the last month of the summer, I have spread out my outer robe folded in four and lain down in the lion’s posture—on the right side, placing one foot on top of the other—mindful and aware.”
translation_text.mn36:46.2: “Some ascetics and brahmins call that a deluded abiding.”
translation_text.mn36:46.3: “That’s not how to define whether someone is deluded or not.
translation_text.mn36:46.4: But as to how to define whether someone is deluded or not,
translation_text.mn36:46.5: listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
translation_text.mn36:47.1: “Anyone who has not given up the defilements that are corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death is deluded, I say.
translation_text.mn36:47.2: For it’s not giving up the defilements that makes you deluded.
translation_text.mn36:47.3: Anyone who has given up the defilements that are corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death—is not deluded, I say.
translation_text.mn36:47.4: For it’s giving up the defilements that makes you not deluded.
translation_text.mn36:47.5: The Realized One has given up the defilements that are corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death. He has cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, obliterated them so they are unable to arise in the future.
translation_text.mn36:47.6: Just as a palm tree with its crown cut off is incapable of further growth,
translation_text.mn36:47.7: in the same way, the Realized One has given up the defilements so they are unable to arise in the future.”
translation_text.mn36:48.1: When he had spoken, Saccaka said to him,
translation_text.mn36:48.3: How when the worthy Gotama is repeatedly attacked with inappropriate and intrusive criticism, the complexion of his skin brightens and the color of his face becomes clear, just like a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha!
translation_text.mn36:48.4: I recall taking on Pūraṇa Kassapa in debate.
translation_text.mn36:48.5: He dodged the issue, distracting the discussion with irrelevant points, and displaying annoyance, hate, and bitterness.
translation_text.mn36:48.6: But when the worthy Gotama is repeatedly attacked with inappropriate and intrusive criticism, the complexion of his skin brightens and the color of his face becomes clear, just like a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha.
translation_text.mn36:48.7: I recall taking on the bamboo-staffed ascetic Gosāla,
translation_text.mn36:48.11: and the Jain ascetic of the Ñātika clan in debate.
translation_text.mn36:48.12: They all dodged the issue, distracting the discussion with irrelevant points, and displaying annoyance, hate, and bitterness.
translation_text.mn36:48.13: But when the worthy Gotama is repeatedly attacked with inappropriate and intrusive criticism, the complexion of his skin brightens and the color of his face becomes clear, just like a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha.
translation_text.mn36:48.14: Well, now, worthy Gotama, I must go.
translation_text.mn36:48.15: I have many duties, and much to do.”
translation_text.mn36:48.17: Then Saccaka, the son of Jain parents, having approved and agreed with what the Buddha said, got up from his seat and left.
